titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Willetts family deeds 1977.475
titlestmt.author: Nicholas Pavlik
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection was originally processed and described as part of the project, "Uncovering the Secrets of Brooklyn's 19th Century Past: Creation to Consolidation," funded by the Council on Library and Information Resources, with additional support from The Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-11-29 21:43:14 +0000.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.abstract: This collection consists of three 1719-1801 deeds involving members of the Willetts family of Queens County, N.Y.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This small collection is housed in a single folder.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); Willetts family deeds, 1977.475, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Public Library, Center for Brooklyn History.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Minimally processed to the collection level. This collection was rehoused and the finding aid revised by Dee Bowers in 2023.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of three deeds involving members of the Willetts family (also spelled Willets and Willits in the deeds) of Queens County, N.Y. Included are a deed for land in Oyster Bay sold by Thomas Bound to Jacob Willetts; a deed for land in Jericho owned by Jacob Willetts and sold to his brothers Richard and Amos Willetts; and a deed for land in Jericho owned by Richard Willets and given to his son Richard Willets, Jr. Documents date from the period 1719 to 1801. Both Jericho and Oyster Bay would become part of Nassau County, Long Island in 1898.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The materials in this collection are in the public domain. While many items at the Center for Brooklyn History are unrestricted, we do not own reproduction rights to all materials. Be aware of the several kinds of rights that might apply: copyright, licensing and trademarks. The researcher assumes all responsibility for copyright questions.
